**Cape Verde** ([/ˌkeɪp ˈvɜːrd/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English "Help:IPA/English"))
or **Cabo Verde** ([/ˌkɑːboʊ ˈvɜːrdeɪ/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English
"Help:IPA/English"), [/ˌkæb-/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English "Help:IPA/English"))
([Portuguese](/wiki/Portuguese_language "Portuguese language"): _Cabo Verde_ ,
pronounced [[ˈkaβu ˈveɾðɨ]](/wiki/Help:IPA/Portuguese "Help:IPA/Portuguese")),
officially the **Republic of Cabo Verde** ,[9] is an [island
country](/wiki/Island_country "Island country") spanning an
[archipelago](/wiki/Archipelago "Archipelago") of 10 [volcanic
islands](/wiki/High_island "High island") in the central [Atlantic
Ocean](/wiki/Atlantic_Ocean "Atlantic Ocean"). It forms part of the
[Macaronesia](/wiki/Macaronesia "Macaronesia") [ecoregion](/wiki/Ecoregion
"Ecoregion"), along with the [Azores](/wiki/Azores "Azores"), [Canary
Islands](/wiki/Canary_Islands "Canary Islands"), [Madeira](/wiki/Madeira
"Madeira"), and the [Savage Isles](/wiki/Savage_Isles "Savage Isles"). In
ancient times these islands were referred to as "the Islands of the Blessed"
or the "Fortunate Isles". Located 570 kilometres (350 mi) west of the [Cape
Verde Peninsula](/wiki/Cape_Verde_Peninsula "Cape Verde Peninsula") in [West
Africa](/wiki/West_Africa "West Africa"), the islands cover a combined area of
slightly over 4,000 square kilometres (1,500 sq mi).

The Cape Verde archipelago was uninhabited until the 15th century, when
[Portuguese](/wiki/Portuguese_Empire "Portuguese Empire") explorers discovered
and [colonized](/wiki/Colony "Colony") the islands, establishing the first
European settlement in the tropics. Ideally located for the [Atlantic slave
trade](/wiki/Atlantic_slave_trade "Atlantic slave trade"), the islands grew
prosperous throughout the 16th and 17th centuries, attracting merchants,
[privateers](/wiki/Privateer "Privateer"), and [pirates](/wiki/Piracy
"Piracy"). The end of slavery in the 19th century led to economic decline and
emigration. Cape Verde gradually recovered as an important commercial center
and stopover for shipping routes. Incorporated as an overseas department of
Portugal in 1951, the islands continued to campaign for independence, which
was peacefully achieved in 1975.

Since the early 1990s, Cape Verde has been a stable [representative
democracy](/wiki/Representative_democracy "Representative democracy"), and
remains one of the most developed and democratic countries in Africa. Lacking
natural resources, its developing economy is mostly service-oriented, with a
growing focus on tourism and foreign investment. Its population of around
512,000 is mostly of mixed European, [Moorish](/wiki/Moorish "Moorish"),
[Arab](/wiki/Arab "Arab") and African heritage, and predominantly Roman
Catholic, reflecting the legacy of Portuguese rule. A [sizeable diaspora
community](/wiki/Cape_Verdean_diaspora "Cape Verdean diaspora") exists across
the world, slightly outnumbering inhabitants on the islands.

Historically, the name "Cape Verde" has been used in English for the
archipelago and, since independence in 1975, for the country. In 2013, the
Cape Verdean government determined that the Portuguese designation _Cabo
Verde_ would henceforth be used for official purposes, such as at the [United
Nations](/wiki/United_Nations "United Nations"), even in English contexts.
Cape Verde is a member of the [African Union](/wiki/African_Union "African
Union").

## Etymology[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cape_Verde&action=edit&section=1 "Edit
section: Etymology")]

The name of the country stems from the nearby [Cap-Vert](/wiki/Cap-Vert "Cap-
Vert"), on the [Senegalese](/wiki/Senegal "Senegal") coast.[10] In 1444
Portuguese explorers had named that landmark as _Cabo Verde,_ a few years
before they discovered the islands (_Verde_ is
[Portuguese](/wiki/Portuguese_language "Portuguese language") for "green").

On 24 October 2013, the country's delegation announced at the United Nations
that the official name should no longer be translated into other languages.
Instead of "Cape Verde", the designation "Republic of Cabo Verde" is to be
used.[9][11]

## History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cape_Verde&action=edit&section=2 "Edit
section: History")]

Main article: [History of Cape Verde](/wiki/History_of_Cape_Verde "History of
Cape Verde")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Insulae_Capitis_viridis-1598.jpg/250px-
Insulae_Capitis_viridis-1598.jpg)](/wiki/File:Insulae_Capitis_viridis-1598.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Insulae_Capitis_viridis-1598.jpg "Enlarge")

_Insulae Capitis Viridis_ (1598), showing Cape Verde

Before the arrival of Europeans, the Cape Verde Islands were uninhabited.[12]
The islands of the Cape Verde archipelago were discovered by
[Genoese](/wiki/Genoa "Genoa") and Portuguese [navigators](/wiki/Navigator
"Navigator") around 1456. According to Portuguese official records,[13] the
first discoveries were made by [Genoa](/wiki/Genoa "Genoa")-born [António de
Noli](/wiki/Ant%C3%B3nio_de_Noli "António de Noli"), who was afterwards
appointed governor of Cape Verde by Portuguese [King Afonso
V](/wiki/Afonso_V_of_Portugal "Afonso V of Portugal"). Other navigators
mentioned as contributing to discoveries in the Cape Verde archipelago are
[Diogo Gomes](/wiki/Diogo_Gomes "Diogo Gomes") (who was with António de Noli
and claimed to have been the first to land on and name Santiago island),
[Diogo Dias](/wiki/Diogo_Dias "Diogo Dias"), Diogo Afonso and the Italian
(Venice-born) [Alvise Cadamosto](/wiki/Alvise_Cadamosto "Alvise Cadamosto").

In 1462, Portuguese settlers arrived at [Santiago](/wiki/Santiago,_Cape_Verde
"Santiago, Cape Verde") and founded a settlement they called Ribeira Grande
(now called [Cidade Velha](/wiki/Cidade_Velha "Cidade Velha"), to avoid being
confused with the town of [Ribeira Grande](/wiki/Ribeira_Grande,_Cape_Verde
"Ribeira Grande, Cape Verde") on the [Santo
Antão](/wiki/Santo_Ant%C3%A3o,_Cape_Verde "Santo Antão, Cape Verde") island).
Ribeira Grande was the first permanent European settlement in the
[tropics](/wiki/Tropics "Tropics").[14]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/Mindelo-
MontCara2000.jpg/250px-Mindelo-MontCara2000.jpg)](/wiki/File:Mindelo-
MontCara2000.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Mindelo-MontCara2000.jpg "Enlarge")

A view of [Monte Cara](/wiki/Monte_Cara "Monte Cara") from
[Mindelo](/wiki/Mindelo "Mindelo")

In the 16th century, the archipelago prospered from the [Atlantic slave
trade](/wiki/Atlantic_slave_trade "Atlantic slave trade").[14] Pirates
occasionally attacked the Portuguese settlements. [Francis
Drake](/wiki/Francis_Drake "Francis Drake"), an English
[privateer](/wiki/Privateer "Privateer"), twice sacked the (then) capital
[Ribeira Grande](/wiki/Cidade_Velha "Cidade Velha") in 1585 when it was a part
of the [Iberian Union](/wiki/Iberian_Union "Iberian Union").[14] After a
French attack in 1712, the town declined in importance relative to nearby
[Praia](/wiki/Praia "Praia"), which became the capital in 1770.[14]

Decline in the slave trade in the 19th century resulted in an economic crisis.
Cape Verde's early prosperity slowly vanished. However, the islands' position
astride mid-Atlantic shipping lanes made Cape Verde an ideal location for re-
supplying ships. Because of its excellent harbour, the city of
[Mindelo](/wiki/Mindelo "Mindelo"), located on the island of [São
Vicente](/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Vicente,_Cape_Verde "São Vicente, Cape Verde"), became
an important commercial centre during the 19th century.[14] Diplomat [Edmund
Roberts](/wiki/Edmund_Roberts_\(diplomat\) "Edmund Roberts \(diplomat\)")
visited Cape Verde in 1832.[15]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/Garthpool_SLV_AllanGreen.jpg/250px-
Garthpool_SLV_AllanGreen.jpg)](/wiki/File:Garthpool_SLV_AllanGreen.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Garthpool_SLV_AllanGreen.jpg "Enlarge")

Grain ship _Garthpool_ , wrecked at Boavista, Cape Verde, in 1928

With few natural resources and inadequate sustainable investment from the
Portuguese, the citizens grew increasingly discontented with the colonial
masters, who nevertheless refused to provide the local authorities with more
autonomy. In 1951, Portugal changed Cape Verde's status from a colony to an
overseas province in an attempt to blunt growing
[nationalism](/wiki/Nationalism "Nationalism"). In 1956, [Amílcar
Cabral](/wiki/Am%C3%ADlcar_Cabral "Amílcar Cabral") and a group of fellow Cape
Verdeans and Guineans organised (in [Portuguese
Guinea](/wiki/Portuguese_Guinea "Portuguese Guinea")) the clandestine [African
Party for the Independence of Guinea and Cape
Verde](/wiki/African_Party_for_the_Independence_of_Guinea_and_Cape_Verde
"African Party for the Independence of Guinea and Cape Verde") (PAIGC).[14]

It demanded improvement in economic, social and political conditions in Cape
Verde and Portuguese Guinea and formed the basis of the two nations'
independence movement. Moving its headquarters to [Conakry](/wiki/Conakry
"Conakry"), Guinea in 1960, the PAIGC began an armed rebellion against
Portugal in 1961. Acts of sabotage eventually grew into a [war in Portuguese
Guinea](/wiki/Guinea-Bissau_War_of_Independence "Guinea-Bissau War of
Independence") that pitted 10,000 [Soviet Bloc](/wiki/Eastern_Bloc "Eastern
Bloc")-supported PAIGC soldiers against 35,000 Portuguese and African
troops.[14]

By 1972, the PAIGC controlled much of Portuguese Guinea despite the presence
of the Portuguese troops, but the organization did not attempt to disrupt
Portuguese control in Cape Verde. Portuguese Guinea declared independence in
1973 and was granted [de jure](/wiki/De_jure "De jure") independence in 1974.
A budding independence movement — originally led by [Amílcar
Cabral](/wiki/Am%C3%ADlcar_Cabral "Amílcar Cabral"), assassinated in 1973 —
passed on to his half-brother [Luís Cabral](/wiki/Lu%C3%ADs_Cabral "Luís
Cabral") and culminated in independence for the archipelago in 1975.

### Independence
(1975)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cape_Verde&action=edit&section=3 "Edit
section: Independence \(1975\)")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/Stamps_of_Germany_%28DDR%29_1978%2C_MiNr_2293.jpg/220px-
Stamps_of_Germany_%28DDR%29_1978%2C_MiNr_2293.jpg)](/wiki/File:Stamps_of_Germany_\(DDR\)_1978,_MiNr_2293.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Stamps_of_Germany_\(DDR\)_1978,_MiNr_2293.jpg "Enlarge")

[Amílcar Cabral](/wiki/Am%C3%ADlcar_Cabral "Amílcar Cabral") on a stamp of the
former [East Germany](/wiki/East_Germany "East Germany")

Following the [April 1974 revolution in Portugal](/wiki/Carnation_Revolution
"Carnation Revolution"), the PAIGC became an active political movement in Cape
Verde. In December 1974, the PAIGC and Portugal signed an agreement providing
for a transitional government composed of Portuguese and Cape Verdeans. On 30
June 1975, Cape Verdeans elected a National Assembly which received the
instruments of independence from Portugal on 5 July 1975.[14] In the late
1970s and 1980s, most African countries prohibited [South African
Airways](/wiki/South_African_Airways "South African Airways") from overflights
but Cape Verde allowed them and became a centre of activity for the airline's
flights to Europe and the United States.

Immediately following the [November 1980 coup in Guinea-
Bissau](/wiki/History_of_Guinea-Bissau#Independence_from_Portugal "History of
Guinea-Bissau"), relations between Cape Verde and Guinea-Bissau became
strained. Cape Verde abandoned its hope for unity with Guinea-Bissau and
formed the [African Party for the Independence of Cape
Verde](/wiki/African_Party_for_the_Independence_of_Cape_Verde "African Party
for the Independence of Cape Verde") (PAICV). Problems have since been
resolved and [relations between the
countries](/wiki/Cape_Verde%E2%80%93Guinea-Bissau_relations "Cape
Verde–Guinea-Bissau relations") are good. The PAICV and its predecessor
established a one-party system and ruled Cape Verde from independence until
1990.[14]

Responding to growing pressure for pluralistic democracy, the PAICV called an
emergency congress in February 1990 to discuss proposed constitutional changes
to end one-party rule. Opposition groups came together to form the [Movement
for Democracy](/wiki/Movement_for_Democracy_\(Cape_Verde\) "Movement for
Democracy \(Cape Verde\)") (MPD) in Praia in April 1990. Together, they
campaigned for the right to contest the presidential election scheduled for
December 1990.

The one-party state was abolished 28 September 1990, and the first multi-party
elections were held in January 1991. The MPD won a majority of the seats in
the National Assembly, and MPD presidential candidate [António Mascarenhas
Monteiro](/wiki/Ant%C3%B3nio_Mascarenhas_Monteiro "António Mascarenhas
Monteiro") defeated the PAICV's candidate with 73.5% of the votes. Legislative
elections in December 1995 increased the MPD majority in the National
Assembly. The party won 50 of the National Assembly's 72 seats.

A February 1996 presidential election returned President Monteiro to office.
Legislative elections in January 2001 returned power to the PAICV, with the
PAICV holding 40 of the National Assembly seats, MPD 30, and [Party for
Democratic Convergence](/wiki/Party_for_Democratic_Convergence "Party for
Democratic Convergence") (PCD) and [Labour and Solidarity
Party](/wiki/Labour_and_Solidarity_Party "Labour and Solidarity Party") (PTS)
1 each. In February 2001, the PAICV-supported presidential candidate [Pedro
Pires](/wiki/Pedro_Pires "Pedro Pires") defeated former MPD leader [Carlos
Veiga](/wiki/Carlos_Veiga "Carlos Veiga") by only 13 votes.[14]

## Politics[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cape_Verde&action=edit&section=4 "Edit
section: Politics")]

Main article: [Politics of Cape Verde](/wiki/Politics_of_Cape_Verde "Politics
of Cape Verde")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/Secretary_of_Defense_Chuck_Hagel%2C_right%2C_escorts_Cape_Verde_Prime_Minister_Jose_Maria_Neves_through_an_honor_cordon_and_into_the_Pentagon_on_March_28%2C_2013_130328-D-TT977-063.jpg/250px-
thumbnail.jpg)](/wiki/File:Secretary_of_Defense_Chuck_Hagel,_right,_escorts_Cape_Verde_Prime_Minister_Jose_Maria_Neves_through_an_honor_cordon_and_into_the_Pentagon_on_March_28,_2013_130328-D-TT977-063.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Secretary_of_Defense_Chuck_Hagel,_right,_escorts_Cape_Verde_Prime_Minister_Jose_Maria_Neves_through_an_honor_cordon_and_into_the_Pentagon_on_March_28,_2013_130328-D-TT977-063.jpg
"Enlarge")

Cape Verdean Prime Minister [José Maria Neves](/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Maria_Neves
"José Maria Neves") meets with the US Secretary of Defense [Chuck
Hagel](/wiki/Chuck_Hagel "Chuck Hagel"), in 2013.

Cape Verde is a stable [semi-presidential](/wiki/Semi-presidential_system
"Semi-presidential system") [representative
democratic](/wiki/Representative_democracy "Representative democracy")
[republic](/wiki/Republic "Republic").[4][16] It is among the most democratic
nations in the world, ranking 23rd position in the world, according to the
_2016[Democracy Index](/wiki/Democracy_Index "Democracy Index")_.[17] The
[constitution](https://www.constituteproject.org/constitution/Cape_Verde_1992?lang=en)
— adopted in 1980 and revised in 1992, 1995 and 1999 — defines the basic
principles of its government. The [president](/wiki/President_of_Cape_Verde
"President of Cape Verde") is the [head of state](/wiki/Head_of_state "Head of
state") and is elected by [popular vote](/wiki/Direct_election "Direct
election") for a 5-year term.[14]

The [prime minister](/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Cape_Verde "Prime Minister of
Cape Verde") is the [head of government](/wiki/Head_of_government "Head of
government") and proposes other ministers and secretaries of state. The prime
minister is nominated by the [National
Assembly](/wiki/National_Assembly_\(Cape_Verde\) "National Assembly \(Cape
Verde\)") and appointed by the president.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] Members
of the National Assembly are elected by popular vote for 5-year terms. Three
parties now hold seats in the National Assembly — MPD (36), PAICV (25) and the
Cape Verdean Independent Democratic Union (UCID) (3).[18]

The judicial system consists of a Supreme Court of Justice — whose members are
appointed by the president, the National Assembly, and the Board of the
Judiciary — and regional courts. Separate courts hear civil, constitutional,
and criminal cases. Appeal is to the Supreme Court.[14]

The two main political parties are PAICV and MPD.[18]

### Foreign
relations[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cape_Verde&action=edit&section=5 "Edit
section: Foreign relations")]

Further information: [Foreign relations of Cape
Verde](/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_Cape_Verde "Foreign relations of Cape
Verde")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/47/Cape_Verdean_embassies.PNG/250px-
Cape_Verdean_embassies.PNG)](/wiki/File:Cape_Verdean_embassies.PNG)

[](/wiki/File:Cape_Verdean_embassies.PNG "Enlarge")

Map of countries with Cape Verdean embassies

Cape Verde follows a policy of [nonalignment](/wiki/Non-Aligned_Movement "Non-
Aligned Movement") and seeks cooperative relations with all friendly
states.[14] [Angola](/wiki/Angola "Angola"), Brazil, the [People's Republic of
China](/wiki/People%27s_Republic_of_China "People's Republic of China"),
[Libya](/wiki/Libya "Libya"), [Cuba](/wiki/Cuba "Cuba"), [France](/wiki/France
"France"), [Germany](/wiki/Germany "Germany"), [Portugal](/wiki/Portugal
"Portugal"), [Spain](/wiki/Spain "Spain"), [Senegal](/wiki/Senegal "Senegal"),
[Russia](/wiki/Russia "Russia"), [Luxembourg](/wiki/Luxembourg "Luxembourg"),
and the [United States](/wiki/United_States "United States") maintain
embassies in Praia.[14] Cape Verde is actively interested in foreign
affairs[_[clarification needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Please_clarify
"Wikipedia:Please clarify")_], especially in Africa.[14]

Cape Verde has [bilateral relations](/wiki/Bilateralism "Bilateralism") with
some [Lusophone](/wiki/Lusophone "Lusophone") nations and holds membership in
a number of international organisations.[14] It also participates in most
international conferences on economic and political issues.[14] Since 2007,
Cape Verde has a _special partnership_ status[19] with the
[EU](/wiki/European_Union "European Union"), under the [Cotonou
Agreement](/wiki/Cotonou_Agreement "Cotonou Agreement"), and might apply for
[special
membership](/wiki/Cape_Verde%E2%80%93European_Union_relations#Membership "Cape
Verde–European Union relations"), even because the [Cape Verdean
escudo](/wiki/Cape_Verdean_escudo "Cape Verdean escudo"), the country's
currency, is indexed to the [Euro](/wiki/Euro "Euro").[20] In 2011 Cape Verde
ratified the [Rome Statute of the International Criminal
Court](/wiki/Rome_Statute_of_the_International_Criminal_Court "Rome Statute of
the International Criminal Court").[21]

### Military[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cape_Verde&action=edit&section=6 "Edit
section: Military")]

Main article: [Cape Verdean Armed Forces](/wiki/Cape_Verdean_Armed_Forces
"Cape Verdean Armed Forces")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9a/Marins_du_Cap-
Vert_en_2011.jpg/220px-Marins_du_Cap-
Vert_en_2011.jpg)](/wiki/File:Marins_du_Cap-Vert_en_2011.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Marins_du_Cap-Vert_en_2011.jpg "Enlarge")

Marines of the Cape Verdean Coast Guard

The [military of Cape Verde](/wiki/Cape_Verdean_Armed_Forces "Cape Verdean
Armed Forces") consists of a National Guard and the Coast Guard; 0.7% of the
country's GDP was spent on the military in 2005.

Having fought their only [war for independence](/wiki/Guinea-
Bissau_War_of_Independence "Guinea-Bissau War of Independence") against
Portugal between 1974 and 1975, the efforts of the Caboverdean Armed Forces
have now been turned to combating international drug trafficking. In 2007,
together with the [Cabo Verdean
Police](/w/index.php?title=Cabo_Verdean_Police&action=edit&redlink=1 "Cabo
Verdean Police \(page does not exist\)"), they carried out Operation Flying
Launch (_Operacão Lancha Voador_ a), a successful operation to put an end to a
drug trafficking group which smuggled cocaine from [Colombia](/wiki/Colombia
"Colombia") to the [Netherlands](/wiki/Netherlands "Netherlands") and
[Germany](/wiki/Germany "Germany") using the country as a reorder point. The
operation took more than three years, being a secret operation during the
first two years, and ended in 2010.

Although located in Africa, Cape Verde has always had close relations with
Europe. Because of this, some scholars argue that Cape Verde may be eligible
to join the [Organization for Security and Co-operation in
Europe](/wiki/Organization_for_Security_and_Co-operation_in_Europe
"Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe") and [NATO](/wiki/NATO
"NATO").[22]

The most recent engagement of the Armed Forces was the [Monte Tchota
massacre](/wiki/Monte_Tchota_massacre "Monte Tchota massacre") that resulted
in 11 deaths.[23]

## Geography[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cape_Verde&action=edit&section=8 "Edit
section: Geography")]

Main article: [Geography of Cape Verde](/wiki/Geography_of_Cape_Verde
"Geography of Cape Verde")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/Topographic_map_of_Cape_Verde-
en.svg/220px-Topographic_map_of_Cape_Verde-
en.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Topographic_map_of_Cape_Verde-en.svg)

[](/wiki/File:Topographic_map_of_Cape_Verde-en.svg "Enlarge")

A [topographic map](/wiki/Topographic_map "Topographic map") of Cape Verde

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2b/Cape_Verde.2010-11-23.250m-per-
px.jpg/220px-Cape_Verde.2010-11-23.250m-per-
px.jpg)](/wiki/File:Cape_Verde.2010-11-23.250m-per-px.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Cape_Verde.2010-11-23.250m-per-px.jpg "Enlarge")

A satellite photo of the Cape Verde islands, 2010

The Cape Verde archipelago is in the Atlantic Ocean, approximately 570
kilometres (350 mi) off the western coast of the African continent, near
Senegal, The Gambia, and [Mauritania](/wiki/Mauritania "Mauritania"), and is
part of the [Macaronesia](/wiki/Macaronesia "Macaronesia")
[ecoregion](/wiki/Ecoregion "Ecoregion"). It lies between latitudes
[14°](/wiki/14th_parallel_north "14th parallel north") and
[18°N](/wiki/18th_parallel_north "18th parallel north"), and longitudes
[22°](/wiki/22nd_meridian_west "22nd meridian west") and
[26°W](/wiki/26th_meridian_west "26th meridian west").

The country is a horseshoe-shaped cluster of ten islands (nine inhabited) and
eight islets,[27] that constitute an area of 4033 km2.[27]

The islands are spatially divided into two groups:

  * The [Barlavento Islands](/wiki/Barlavento_Islands "Barlavento Islands") ([windward](/wiki/Windward_and_leeward "Windward and leeward") islands): [Santo Antão](/wiki/Santo_Ant%C3%A3o,_Cape_Verde "Santo Antão, Cape Verde"), [São Vicente](/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Vicente,_Cape_Verde "São Vicente, Cape Verde"), [Santa Luzia](/wiki/Santa_Luzia,_Cape_Verde "Santa Luzia, Cape Verde"), [São Nicolau](/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Nicolau,_Cape_Verde "São Nicolau, Cape Verde"), [Sal](/wiki/Sal,_Cape_Verde "Sal, Cape Verde"), [Boa Vista](/wiki/Boa_Vista,_Cape_Verde "Boa Vista, Cape Verde");[27] and
  * The [Sotavento Islands](/wiki/Sotavento_Islands "Sotavento Islands") ([leeward](/wiki/Windward_and_leeward "Windward and leeward")): [Maio](/wiki/Maio,_Cape_Verde "Maio, Cape Verde"), [Santiago](/wiki/Santiago,_Cape_Verde "Santiago, Cape Verde"), [Fogo](/wiki/Fogo,_Cape_Verde "Fogo, Cape Verde"), [Brava](/wiki/Brava,_Cape_Verde "Brava, Cape Verde").[27]

The largest island, both in size and population, is Santiago, which hosts the
nation's capital, Praia, the principal urban agglomeration in the
archipelago.[27]

Three of the Cape Verde islands, Sal, Boa Vista and Maio, are fairly flat,
sandy, and dry; the others are generally rockier with more vegetation.

### Physical geography and
geology[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cape_Verde&action=edit&section=9 "Edit
section: Physical geography and geology")]

Geologically, the islands, covering a combined area of slightly over 4,033
square kilometres (1,557 square miles), are principally composed of [igneous
rocks](/wiki/Igneous_rock "Igneous rock"), with volcanic structures and
[pyroclastic](/wiki/Pyroclastic_rock "Pyroclastic rock") debris comprising the
majority of the archipelago's total volume. The [volcanic](/wiki/Volcano
"Volcano") and [plutonic rocks](/wiki/Pluton "Pluton") are distinctly basic;
the archipelago is a soda-alkaline [petrographic](/wiki/Petrography
"Petrography") province, with a [petrologic](/wiki/Petrology "Petrology")
succession similar to that found in other [Macaronesian](/wiki/Macaronesia
"Macaronesia") islands.

Magnetic anomalies identified in the vicinity of the archipelago indicate that
the structures forming the islands date back 125–150 million years: the
islands themselves date from 8 million (in the west) to 20 million years (in
the east).[28] The oldest exposed rocks occurred on Maio and northern
peninsula of Santiago and are 128–131 million year old pillow lavas. The first
stage of volcanism in the islands began in the early [Miocene](/wiki/Miocene
"Miocene"), and reached its peak at the end of this period, when the islands
reached their maximum sizes. Historical volcanism (within human settlement)
has been restricted to the island of Fogo.

The origin of the islands' volcanism has been attributed to a
[hotspot](/wiki/Hotspot_\(geology\) "Hotspot \(geology\)"), associated with
bathymetric swell that formed the [Cape Verde Rise](/wiki/Cape_Verde_Rise
"Cape Verde Rise").[29] The Rise is one of the largest protuberances in the
world's oceans, rising 2.2 kilometres (1.4 miles) in a semi-circular region of
1200 km2, associated with a rise of the [geoid](/wiki/Geoid "Geoid") and
elevated surface heat flow.[28]

Most recently erupting in 2014, [Pico do Fogo](/wiki/Pico_do_Fogo "Pico do
Fogo") is the largest active [volcano](/wiki/Volcano "Volcano") in the region.
It has a 8 kilometres (5 miles) diameter [caldera](/wiki/Caldera "Caldera"),
whose rim is 1,600 metres (5,249 feet) altitude and an interior cone that
rises to 2,829 metres (9,281 feet) [above sea level](/wiki/Above_sea_level
"Above sea level"). The caldera resulted from subsidence, following the
partial evacuation (eruption) of the [magma](/wiki/Magma "Magma") chamber,
along a cylindrical column from within magma chamber (at a depth of 8
kilometres (5 miles)).

Extensive [salt flats](/wiki/Salt_pan_\(geology\) "Salt pan \(geology\)") are
found on Sal and Maio.[27] On Santiago, Santo Antão, and São Nicolau, arid
slopes give way in places to sugarcane fields or banana plantations spread
along the base of towering mountains.[27] Ocean cliffs have been formed by
catastrophic [debris landslides](/wiki/Landslide#Debris_landslide
"Landslide").[30]

According to the president of [Nauru](/wiki/Nauru "Nauru"), Cape Verde has
been ranked the eighth most endangered nation due to flooding from [climate
change](/wiki/Climate_change "Climate change").[31]

### Climate[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cape_Verde&action=edit&section=10 "Edit
section: Climate")]

Further information: [Geography of Cape Verde §
Climate](/wiki/Geography_of_Cape_Verde#Climate "Geography of Cape Verde")

Cape Verde's climate is milder than that of the African mainland, because the
surrounding sea moderates temperatures on the islands and cold Atlantic
currents produce an arid atmosphere around the archipelago. Conversely, the
islands do not receive the upwellings (cold streams) that affect the West
African coast, so the air temperature is cooler than in Senegal, but the sea
is warmer, because the orographic relief of some islands, such as Santiago
with steep mountains, cover it with rich woods and luxuriant vegetation where
the humid air condenses and soak the plants, rocks, soil, logs, moss, etc. On
the higher islands and somewhat wetter islands, exclusively in mountainous
areas, like Santo Antão island, the climate is suitable for the development of
dry monsoon forest, and laurel forest as this vegetation[27] Average daily
high temperatures range from 26 °C (79 °F) in February to 31 °C (87.8 °F) in
September.[32] Cape Verde is part of the [Sahelian arid belt](/wiki/Sahel
"Sahel"), with nothing like the rainfall levels of nearby West Africa.[27] It
rains irregularly between August and October, with frequent brief heavy
downpours.[27] A _desert_ is usually defined as terrain that receives less
than 250 mm (9.8 in) of annual rainfall. Sal's total of (145 mm (5.7 in))
confirms this classification. Most of the year's rain falls in September.[33]

Sal, Boa Vista and Maio have a flat landscape and arid climate, the remaining
ones are generally rockier and have more vegetation. Because of the infrequent
occurrence of rainfall the landscape is arid. The archipelago can be divided
into four broad ecological zones — arid, semiarid, subhumid and humid,
according to altitude and average annual rainfall ranging from 200 millimetres
(7.9 inches) in the arid areas of the coast to more than 1,000 millimetres (39
inches) in the humid mountain. Most rainfall precipitation is due to
condensation of the ocean mist.

In some islands, as [Santiago](/wiki/Santiago,_Cape_Verde "Santiago, Cape
Verde"), the wetter climate of the interior and the eastern coast contrasts
with the dryer one in the south/southwest coast. Praia, on the southeast
coast, is the largest city of the island and the largest city and capital of
the country.

Because of their proximity to the Sahara, most of the Cape Verde islands are
dry, but on islands with high mountains and farther away from the coast, by
orography, the humidity is much higher, providing a rainforest habitat,
although much affected by the human presence. Northeastern slopes of high
mountains often receive a lot of rain while southwest slopes do not. These
umbria areas are identified with cool and moisture.

Western Hemisphere-bound hurricanes often have their early beginnings near the
Cape Verde Islands. These are referred to as [Cape Verde-type
hurricanes](/wiki/Cape_Verde-type_hurricane "Cape Verde-type hurricane").
These hurricanes can become very intense as they cross warm Atlantic waters
away from Cape Verde. The average hurricane season has about two Cape Verde-
type hurricanes, which are usually the largest and most intense storms of the
season because they often have plenty of warm open ocean over which to develop
before encountering land. The five largest Atlantic tropical cyclones on
record have been Cape Verde-type hurricanes. Most of the longest-lived
tropical cyclones in the Atlantic basin are Cape Verde hurricanes.

The islands themselves have only been struck by hurricanes twice in recorded
history (since 1851): once in 1892, and again in 2015 by [Hurricane
Fred](/wiki/Hurricane_Fred_\(2015\) "Hurricane Fred \(2015\)"), the
easternmost hurricane ever to form in the Atlantic.

### Biome[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cape_Verde&action=edit&section=11 "Edit
section: Biome")]

Main article: [Wildlife of Cape Verde](/wiki/Wildlife_of_Cape_Verde "Wildlife
of Cape Verde")

Cape Verde's isolation has resulted in the islands having a number of
[endemic](/wiki/Endemic_\(ecology\) "Endemic \(ecology\)")
[species](/wiki/Species "Species"), particularly birds and reptiles, many of
which are [endangered](/wiki/Endangered_species "Endangered species") by human
development. Endemic birds include [Alexander's
swift](/wiki/Alexander%27s_swift "Alexander's swift") (_Apus alexandri_),
[Bourne's heron](/wiki/Bourne%27s_heron "Bourne's heron") (_Ardea purpurea
bournei_), the [Raso lark](/wiki/Raso_lark "Raso lark") (_Alauda razae_), the
[Cape Verde warbler](/wiki/Cape_Verde_warbler "Cape Verde warbler")
(_Acrocephalus brevipennis_), and the [Iago sparrow](/wiki/Iago_sparrow "Iago
sparrow") (_Passer iagoensis_).[35] The islands are also an important breeding
area for seabirds including the [Cape Verde
shearwater](/wiki/Cape_Verde_shearwater "Cape Verde shearwater"). Reptiles
include the Cape Verde giant gecko (_[Tarentola](/wiki/Tarentola "Tarentola")
gigas_).

### Administrative
divisions[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cape_Verde&action=edit&section=12 "Edit
section: Administrative divisions")]

Main article: [Administrative divisions of Cabo
Verde](/wiki/Administrative_divisions_of_Cabo_Verde "Administrative divisions
of Cabo Verde")

## Economy[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cape_Verde&action=edit&section=14 "Edit
section: Economy")]

Main article: [Economy of Cape Verde](/wiki/Economy_of_Cape_Verde "Economy of
Cape Verde")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8c/Tree_map_export_2009_Cape_Verde.jpeg/350px-
Tree_map_export_2009_Cape_Verde.jpeg)](/wiki/File:Tree_map_export_2009_Cape_Verde.jpeg)

[](/wiki/File:Tree_map_export_2009_Cape_Verde.jpeg "Enlarge")

A proportional representation of Cape Verde's export products

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/TACV_B757_D4-CBG_MUC.jpg/250px-
TACV_B757_D4-CBG_MUC.jpg)](/wiki/File:TACV_B757_D4-CBG_MUC.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:TACV_B757_D4-CBG_MUC.jpg "Enlarge")

Cape Verdean national flag carrier TACV

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/Cape_Verde_Sal_pool.jpg/250px-
Cape_Verde_Sal_pool.jpg)](/wiki/File:Cape_Verde_Sal_pool.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Cape_Verde_Sal_pool.jpg "Enlarge")

A resort in [Sal](/wiki/Sal,_Cape_Verde "Sal, Cape Verde")

Cape Verde's notable economic growth and improvement in living conditions
despite a lack of natural resources has garnered international recognition,
with other countries and international organizations often providing
[development aid](/wiki/Development_aid "Development aid"). Since 2007, the UN
has classified it as a [developing nation](/wiki/Developing_nation "Developing
nation") rather than a [least developed country](/wiki/Least_developed_country
"Least developed country").

Cape Verde has few [natural resources](/wiki/Natural_resource "Natural
resource"). Only five of the ten main islands (Santiago, Santo Antão, São
Nicolau, Fogo, and Brava) normally support significant agricultural
production,[37] and over 90% of all food consumed in Cape Verde is imported.
Mineral resources include salt, [pozzolana](/wiki/Pozzolana "Pozzolana") (a
volcanic rock used in cement production), and [limestone](/wiki/Limestone
"Limestone").[14] Its small number of wineries making Portuguese-style wines
have traditionally focused on the domestic market, but have recently met with
some international acclaim. A number of wine tours of Cape Verde's various
microclimates began to be offered in spring 2010 and can be arranged through
the tourism office.

The economy of Cape Verde is service-oriented, with commerce, transport, and
public services accounting for more than 70% of GDP.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]
Although nearly 35% of the population lives in rural areas, agriculture and
fishing contribute only about 9% of GDP. Light manufacturing accounts for most
of the remainder. Fish and shellfish are plentiful, and small quantities are
exported. Cape Verde has cold storage and freezing facilities and [fish
processing](/wiki/Fish_processing "Fish processing") plants in Mindelo, Praia,
and on Sal. Expatriate Cape Verdeans contribute an amount estimated at about
20% of GDP to the domestic economy through [remittances](/wiki/Remittance
"Remittance").[14] In spite of having few natural resources and being semi-
desert, the country boasts the highest living standards in the region, and has
attracted thousands of immigrants of different nationalities.

Since 1991, the government has pursued market-oriented economic policies,
including an open welcome to [foreign investors](/wiki/Foreign_investors
"Foreign investors") and a far-reaching [privatization](/wiki/Privatization
"Privatization") programme. It established as top development priorities the
promotion of a [market economy](/wiki/Market_economy "Market economy") and of
the private sector; the development of [tourism](/wiki/Tourism_in_Cape_Verde
"Tourism in Cape Verde"), light manufacturing industries, and fisheries; and
the development of [transport](/wiki/Transport_in_Cape_Verde "Transport in
Cape Verde"), [communications](/wiki/Communications_in_Cape_Verde
"Communications in Cape Verde"), and energy facilities. From 1994 to 2000
about $407 million in foreign investments were made or planned, of which 58%
were in tourism,[38] 17% in industry, 4% in infrastructure, and 21% in
fisheries and services.[14]

In 2011, on four islands a wind farm was built that supplies about 30% of the
electricity of the country. It is one of the top countries for renewable
energy.[39]

Between 2000 and 2009, [real GDP](/wiki/Real_GDP "Real GDP") increased on
average by over 7 percent a year, well above the average for Sub-Saharan
countries and faster than most small island economies in the region. Strong
economic performance was bolstered by one of the fastest growing tourism
industries in the world, as well as by substantial capital inflows that
allowed Cape Verde to build up national currency reserves to the current 3.5
months of imports. Unemployment has been falling rapidly, and the country is
on track to achieve most of the UN Millennium Development Goals – including
halving its 1990 poverty level.

In 2007, Cape Verde joined the [World Trade
Organization](/wiki/World_Trade_Organization "World Trade Organization") (WTO)
and in 2008 the country graduated from [Least Developed
Country](/wiki/Least_developed_country "Least developed country") (LDC) to
Middle Income Country (MIC) status.[40][41]

Cape Verde has significant cooperation with Portugal at every level of the
economy, which has led it to link its currency first to the [Portuguese
escudo](/wiki/Portuguese_escudo "Portuguese escudo") and, in 1999, to the
[euro](/wiki/Euro "Euro"). On 23 June 2008 Cape Verde became the 153rd member
of the WTO.[42]

In early January 2018, the government announced that the minimum wage would be
raised to 13,000 CVE (USD 140 or EUR 130) from 11,000 CVE, which was effective
in mid-January 2018. [43][44]

### Development[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cape_Verde&action=edit&section=15
"Edit section: Development")]

The European Commission's total allocation for the period of 2008–2013
foreseen for Cape Verde to address "poverty reduction, in particular in rural
and periurban areas where women are heading the households, as well as good
governance" amounts to €54.1 million.[45]

### Tourism[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cape_Verde&action=edit&section=16 "Edit
section: Tourism")]

Main article: [Tourism in Cape Verde](/wiki/Tourism_in_Cape_Verde "Tourism in
Cape Verde")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/Assomada_%28Avenida%29.jpg/220px-
Assomada_%28Avenida%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Assomada_\(Avenida\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Assomada_\(Avenida\).jpg "Enlarge")

Freedom Avenue in [Assomada](/wiki/Assomada "Assomada"), near the town square

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/Mindelo_portogrande.jpg/220px-
Mindelo_portogrande.jpg)](/wiki/File:Mindelo_portogrande.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Mindelo_portogrande.jpg "Enlarge")

Yachts in Porto Grande, Mindelo on the island of [São
Vicente](/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Vicente,_Cape_Verde "São Vicente, Cape Verde").
Tourism is a growing source of income on the islands.

Cape Verde's strategic location at the crossroads of mid-Atlantic air and sea
lanes has been enhanced by significant improvements at [Mindelo](/wiki/Mindelo
"Mindelo")'s harbour ([Porto Grande](/wiki/Porto_Grande_Bay "Porto Grande
Bay")) and at [Sal's](/wiki/Am%C3%ADlcar_Cabral_International_Airport "Amílcar
Cabral International Airport") and [Praia's international
airports](/wiki/Nelson_Mandela_International_Airport "Nelson Mandela
International Airport"). A [new international
airport](/wiki/Aristides_Pereira_International_Airport "Aristides Pereira
International Airport") was opened in Boa Vista in December 2007, and on the
island of São Vicente, the newest international airport ([Cesária Évora
Airport](/wiki/Ces%C3%A1ria_%C3%89vora_Airport "Cesária Évora Airport")) in
Cape Verde, was opened in late 2009. Ship repair facilities at Mindelo were
opened in 1983.[14]

The major ports are Mindelo and Praia, but all other islands have smaller port
facilities. In addition to the international airport on Sal,
[airports](/wiki/List_of_airports_in_Cape_Verde "List of airports in Cape
Verde") have been built on all of the inhabited islands. All but the airports
on Brava and [Santo Antão](/wiki/Santo_Ant%C3%A3o,_Cape_Verde "Santo Antão,
Cape Verde") enjoy scheduled air service. The archipelago has 3,050 km (1,895
mi) of roads, of which 1,010 km (628 mi) are paved, most using
[cobblestone](/wiki/Cobblestone "Cobblestone").[14]

The country's future economic prospects depend heavily on the maintenance of
aid flows, the encouragement of tourism, remittances, outsourcing labour to
neighbouring African countries, and the momentum of the government's
development programme.[14]

The official Census recorded that Cape Verde had a population of 512,096 in
2013.[46] A large proportion (236,000) of Cape Verdeans live on the main
island, Santiago.[47]

### Ethnic groups[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cape_Verde&action=edit&section=19
"Edit section: Ethnic groups")]

The Cape Verde archipelago was uninhabited when the Portuguese discovered it
in 1456. African slaves were brought to the islands to work on Portuguese
plantations. Most Cape Verdeans are [mulattos](/wiki/Mulatto "Mulatto")
([mestiços](/wiki/Mesti%C3%A7o "Mestiço") in Portuguese), who have mixed
African and European origins; another term is
[creole](/wiki/Creole_peoples#Portuguese_Africa "Creole peoples") meaning
mixed native African and native European descent. Many Cape Verdeans have
emigrated, mainly to the United States and Europe.

European ancestors include Spanish and Italian seamen who were granted land by
the Portuguese Empire, followed by Portuguese settlers and exiles, as well as
Portuguese Muslims and Jews (both of these religious groups were victims of
the [Inquisition](/wiki/Portuguese_Inquisition "Portuguese Inquisition")).
Many foreigners from other parts of the world settled in Cape Verde as their
permanent home. These people came from places such as the Netherlands, France,
Britain, Arab countries (especially Lebanon and Morocco), China (especially
from Macau), India, Indonesia, South America, North America and Brazil
(including people of Portuguese and African descent) and were absorbed into
the mestiço population. Cape Verde's population in the 21st century is mostly
[creole](/wiki/Creole_peoples#Portuguese_Africa "Creole peoples"); the capital
city Praia accounts for a quarter of the country's population. Over 65% of the
population in the archipelago live in urban centers, and the literacy rate is
around 87% (i.e., 91% among men aged 15 and above and 83% among women aged 15
and above) according to the 2013 Cape Verdean census.

A genetic study revealed that the ancestry of the population in Cape Verde is
predominantly European in the male line and West African in the female line;
counted together the percentage is 56% African and 44% European.[48] The high
degree of genetic and ethnic mixture of individuals is a result of centuries
of migration.

### Languages[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cape_Verde&action=edit&section=20
"Edit section: Languages")]

Cape Verde's official language is Portuguese.[1] It is the language of
instruction and government. It is also used in such media as newspapers,
television, and radio.

[Cape Verdean Creole](/wiki/Cape_Verdean_Creole "Cape Verdean Creole") is used
colloquially and is the mother tongue of virtually all Cape Verdeans. The
national constitution calls for the measures to give it parity with
Portuguese.[1] Cape Verdean Creole or Kriolu is a dialect continuum of a
Portuguese-based [creole](/wiki/Creole_language "Creole language"). There is a
substantial body of literature in Creole, especially in the [Santiago
Creole](/wiki/Santiago_Creole "Santiago Creole") and the [São Vicente
Creole](/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Vicente_Creole "São Vicente Creole"). Creole has been
gaining prestige since the nation's independence from Portugal.

The differences between the forms of the language within the islands have been
a major obstacle in the way of standardization of the language. Some people
have advocated the development of two standards: a North (Barlavento)
standard, centered on the São Vicente Creole, and a South (Sotavento)
standard, centered on the Santiago Creole. [Manuel
Veiga](/wiki/Manuel_Veiga_\(writer\) "Manuel Veiga \(writer\)"), PhD, a
linguist and Minister of Culture of Cape Verde, is the premier proponent of
Kriolu's officialization and standardization.[49]

### Religion[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cape_Verde&action=edit&section=21 "Edit
section: Religion")]

Further information: [Religion in Cape Verde](/wiki/Religion_in_Cape_Verde
"Religion in Cape Verde")

Religion in Cape Verde (2010)[50]

[Catholic Church](/wiki/Catholic_Church "Catholic Church") (78.7%)

Other Christian (10.4%)

Other or non-religious (10.9%)

Around 95% of the population are Christian. More than 85% of the population
was nominally [Roman Catholic](/wiki/Roman_Catholic "Roman Catholic") in
2007.[51] For a minority of the population, Catholicism is
[syncretized](/wiki/Syncretism "Syncretism") with African influences.[52]

The largest [Protestant](/wiki/Protestant "Protestant") denomination is the
[Church of the Nazarene](/wiki/Church_of_the_Nazarene "Church of the
Nazarene"); other groups include the [Seventh-day Adventist
Church](/wiki/Seventh-day_Adventist_Church "Seventh-day Adventist Church"),
[The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day
Saints](/wiki/The_Church_of_Jesus_Christ_of_Latter-day_Saints "The Church of
Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints"), the [Assemblies of
God](/wiki/Assemblies_of_God "Assemblies of God"), the [Universal Church of
the Kingdom of God](/wiki/Universal_Church_of_the_Kingdom_of_God "Universal
Church of the Kingdom of God"), and other [Pentecostal](/wiki/Pentecostal
"Pentecostal") and [evangelical](/wiki/Evangelicalism "Evangelicalism")
groups.[51] There is a small [Muslim](/wiki/Muslim "Muslim") community.[51]
There were [Jewish](/wiki/History_of_the_Jews_in_Cape_Verde "History of the
Jews in Cape Verde") settlements on several islands.[53] The number of
[atheists](/wiki/Atheists "Atheists") is estimated at less than 1% of the
population.[51]

### Emigration and
immigration[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cape_Verde&action=edit&section=22 "Edit
section: Emigration and immigration")]

Main article: [Cape Verdean diaspora](/wiki/Cape_Verdean_diaspora "Cape
Verdean diaspora")

Today, more Cape Verdeans live abroad than in Cape Verde itself, with
significant emigrant[54] Cape Verdean communities in the United States
(500,000 of Cape Verdean descent, with a major concentration on the [New
England](/wiki/New_England "New England") coast from [Providence, Rhode
Island](/wiki/Providence,_Rhode_Island "Providence, Rhode Island"), to [New
Bedford, Massachusetts](/wiki/New_Bedford,_Massachusetts "New Bedford,
Massachusetts")).

There are significant Cape Verde populations in Portugal (150,000),
[Angola](/wiki/Angola "Angola") (45,000), [São Tomé and
Príncipe](/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Tom%C3%A9_and_Pr%C3%ADncipe "São Tomé and Príncipe")
(25,000), [Senegal](/wiki/Senegal "Senegal") (25,000), the Netherlands
(20,000, of which 15,000 are concentrated in [Rotterdam](/wiki/Rotterdam
"Rotterdam")), Spain (65,500), United Kingdom (35,500), France (25,000), Italy
(10,000) [Luxembourg](/wiki/Luxembourg "Luxembourg") (7,000) and Scandinavia
(7,000). There is a Cape Verdean community in [Argentina](/wiki/Argentina
"Argentina") numbering 8,000. A large number of Cape Verdeans and people of
Cape Verdean descent who emigrated before 1975 are not included in these
statistics, because Cape Verdeans had Portuguese passports before 1975.

The Chinese make up a sizable and important segment of the immigrant
population in Cape Verde. The immigrants from the nearby West African coast
make up the majority of foreigners in the country. Over the last several
years, a few thousand Europeans and Latin Americans have settled in the
country. On the islands, there are over 22,000 foreigners/naturalized Cape
Verdeans living and working on a permanent basis.

Over the years, Cape Verde has increasingly become a net immigration country
due to its relative high per capita income, political and social stability,
and freedom.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

Emigrants from the Cape Verde islands to North America have a long history of
involvement with the armed forces. Enlisting in aid of the Revolutionary War,
the Civil War, the First and Second World Wars, as well as the Korean and
Vietnam Wars.[55] Cape Verdeans moved to places all over the world, from
[Macau](/wiki/Macau "Macau") to [Haiti](/wiki/Haiti "Haiti"), and Argentina to
northern Europe.[56]

### Health[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cape_Verde&action=edit&section=23 "Edit
section: Health")]

Main article: [Health in Cape Verde](/wiki/Health_in_Cape_Verde "Health in
Cape Verde")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/PraiaCentrodeSa%C3%BAde.jpg/250px-
PraiaCentrodeSa%C3%BAde.jpg)](/wiki/File:PraiaCentrodeSa%C3%BAde.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:PraiaCentrodeSa%C3%BAde.jpg "Enlarge")

A health clinic in a residential area of Praia

The infant mortality rate among Cape Verdean children between 0 and 5 years
old is 17.5 per 1,000 live births according to the latest (2016) data from the
National Statistics Bureau [[1]](http://www.ine.cv/), while the maternal
mortality rate is 42 deaths per 100,000 live births. The HIV-AIDS prevalence
rate among Cape Verdeans between 15 and 49 years old is 0.8% [57].

According to the latest data (2015) from the National Statistics Bureau
[[2]](http://www.ine.cv/), life expectancy at birth in Cape Verde is 71.5
years for males and 79.9 years for females. There are six hospitals in the
Cape Verde archipelago: two central hospitals (one in the capital city of
Praia and one in Mindelo, São Vicente) and four regional hospitals (one in
Santa Catarina (northern Santiago region), one on São Antão, one on Fogo, and
one on Sal). In addition, there are 28 health centers, 35 sanitation centers
and a variety of private clinics located throughout the archipelago.

Cape Verde's population is among the healthiest in Africa. Since its
independence, it has greatly improved its health indicators. Besides having
been promoted to the group of "medium development" countries in 2007, leaving
the [least developed countries](/wiki/Least_developed_countries "Least
developed countries") category (which is only the second time it has happened
to a country[58]), is currently the [10th best
ranked](/wiki/List_of_countries_by_Human_Development_Index#Africa "List of
countries by Human Development Index") country in Africa in its [Human
Development Index](/wiki/Human_Development_Index "Human Development Index").

The total expenditure for health was 7.1% of GDP (2015).

### Education[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cape_Verde&action=edit&section=24
"Edit section: Education")]

Main article: [Education in Cape Verde](/wiki/Education_in_Cape_Verde
"Education in Cape Verde")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/Finalistas_do_jardim_infantil.jpg/250px-
Finalistas_do_jardim_infantil.jpg)](/wiki/File:Finalistas_do_jardim_infantil.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Finalistas_do_jardim_infantil.jpg "Enlarge")

A kindergarten graduation in Santiago island

Although the Cape Verdean educational system is similar to the Portuguese
system, over the years the local universities have been increasingly adopting
the American educational system; for instance, all 10 existing universities in
the country offer 4-year bachelor's degree programs as opposed to 5-year
bachelor's degree programs that existed before 2010. Cape Verde has the second
best educational system in Africa, after South Africa.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] Primary
school education in Cape Verde is mandatory and free for children between the
ages of 6 and 14 years.[59]

In 2011, the net enrollment ratio for primary school was 85%.[59][60]
Approximately 90% of the total population over 15 years of age is literate,
and roughly 25% of the population holds a college degree; a significant number
of these college graduates hold doctorate degrees in different academic
fields. Textbooks have been made available to 90 percent of school children,
and 98 percent of the teachers have attended in-service teacher training.[59]
Although most children have access to education, some problems remain.[59] For
example, there is insufficient spending on school materials, lunches, and
books.[59]

As of October 2016, there were 69 secondary schools throughout the archipelago
(including 19 private secondary schools) and at least 10 universities in the
country which are based on the two islands of Santiago and São Vicente. In
2015, 23% of the Cape Verdean population had either attended or graduated from
secondary schools. When it came to higher education, 9% of Cape Verdean men
and 8% of Cape Verdean women held a bachelor's degree or had attended
universities. The overall college education rate (i.e., college graduates and
undergraduate students) in Cape Verde is about 24%, in relation to the local
college age population [[3]](http://www.ine.cv/).

The total expenditure on education was 5.6% of GDP (2010). The mean years of
schooling of adults over 25 years is 12.

### Science and
technology[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cape_Verde&action=edit&section=25 "Edit
section: Science and technology")]

Main article: [Science and technology in Cape
Verde](/wiki/Science_and_technology_in_Cape_Verde "Science and technology in
Cape Verde")

In 2011, Cape Verde devoted just 0.07% of its GDP to research and development,
among the lowest rates in West Africa. The Ministry of Higher Education,
Science and Culture plans to strengthen the research and academic sectors by
placing emphasis on greater mobility, through exchange programmes and
international co-operation agreements. As part of this strategy, Cape Verde is
participating in the Ibero-American academic mobility programme that expects
to mobilize 200 000 academics between 2015 and 2020.[61]

Cape Verde counted 25 researchers in 2011, a researcher density of 51 per
million inhabitants. The world average was 1,083 per million in 2013. All 25
researchers were working in the government sector in 2011 and one in three
were women (36%). There was no research being conducted in either medical or
agricultural sciences. Of the eight engineers involved in research and
development, one was a woman. Three of the five researchers working in natural
sciences were women, as were three of the six social scientists and two of the
five researchers from the humanities.[61]

In 2015, the government was planning to build a ‘cyber-island’ which would
develop and offer services that include software development, computer
maintenance and back office operations. Approved in 2013, the Praia Technology
Park is a step in this direction. Financed by the [African Development
Bank](/wiki/African_Development_Bank "African Development Bank"), it is
expected to be operational by 2018.[61]

### Crime[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cape_Verde&action=edit&section=26 "Edit
section: Crime")]

Further information: [Crime in Cape Verde](/wiki/Crime_in_Cape_Verde "Crime in
Cape Verde")

Theft and burglary are common in Cape Verde especially in crowds, such as
market places, festivals, and celebrations.[62] Often the perpetrators of
these crimes are gangs of street children.[62] Murders are concentrated in the
major population centres of Praia and Mindelo.[62]

## Culture[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cape_Verde&action=edit&section=27 "Edit
section: Culture")]

Main article: [Culture of Cape Verde](/wiki/Culture_of_Cape_Verde "Culture of
Cape Verde")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5f/Ch%C3%A3_das_Caldeiras-
Musiciens.jpg/220px-Ch%C3%A3_das_Caldeiras-
Musiciens.jpg)](/wiki/File:Ch%C3%A3_das_Caldeiras-Musiciens.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Ch%C3%A3_das_Caldeiras-Musiciens.jpg "Enlarge")

Cape Verdeans are a very musical people; The [Chã das
Caldeiras](/wiki/Ch%C3%A3_das_Caldeiras "Chã das Caldeiras") group is an
example.

In all its aspects, the culture of Cape Verde is characterized by a mixture of
European and African elements. This is not a sum of two cultures, living side
by side, but a third product, totally new, resulting from an exchange that
began five hundred years ago. Much similar to some parts of
[Brazil](/wiki/Brazil "Brazil").

The Cape Verdean case may be situated in the common context of African
nations, in which elites, who questioned European racial and cultural
superiority and who in some cases undertook a long armed struggle against
European imperialism and national liberation, use the rule of Western codes as
the main instrument of internal domination.[27]

Cape Verdean social and cultural patterns are similar to those of rural
Portugal.[27] Football (futebol) games and church activities are typical
sources of social interaction and entertainment.[27] The traditional walk
around the praça ([town square](/wiki/Town_square "Town square")) to meet
friends is practiced regularly in Cape Verde towns.[27]

### Media[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cape_Verde&action=edit&section=28 "Edit
section: Media")]

Further information: [Media of Cape Verde](/wiki/Media_of_Cape_Verde "Media of
Cape Verde")

In towns with electricity, television is available on three channels; one
state owned ([RTC](/wiki/RTC_\(Cape_Verde\) "RTC \(Cape Verde\)") \- TCV) and
three foreign owned, RTI Cabo Verde launched by the Portuguese-based RTI in
2005, on 31 March 2007, [Record Cabo Verde](/wiki/Record_Cabo_Verde "Record
Cabo Verde"), its own version was launched by the Brazilian-based [Rede
Record](/wiki/Rede_Record "Rede Record").[27] Cape Verde has now received [TV
CPLP](/wiki/TV_CPLP "TV CPLP") and some of its programs are broadcast, the
network first aired in 2016. Premium channels includes the Capeverdean
versions of Boom TV and Zap Cabo Verde, two channels owned by Brazil's
Record.[63] Other premium channels are aired in Cape Verde especially
Satellite Network, they are common in hotels and villas but availability is
predominantly limited, one of them is [RDP África](/wiki/RDP_%C3%81frica "RDP
África"), the African version of the Portuguese radio station
[RDP](/wiki/Radiodifus%C3%A3o_Portuguesa "Radiodifusão Portuguesa").

As of early 2017, about 19% of the Cape Verdean population own an active
cellular phone, 70% have access to the Internet, 11% own a landline telephone,
and 2% of the population subscribe to local cable TV. In 2003, Cape Verde had
71,700 main line telephones with an additional 53,300 cellular phones in use
throughout the country.

In 2004, there were seven radio stations; six independent and one state owned.
The media is operated by the Capeverdean News Agency (secondarily as
[Inforpress](/wiki/Inforpress "Inforpress")). Nationwide radio stations
include RCV, RCV+, Radio Kriola, the religious station Radio Nova.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] Local
radio stations include Rádio Praia, the first radio station in Cape Verde,
Praia FM, the first FM station in the nation, [Rádio
Barlavento](/wiki/R%C3%A1dio_Barlavento "Rádio Barlavento"), [Rádio Clube do
Mindelo](/wiki/R%C3%A1dio_Clube_do_Mindelo "Rádio Clube do Mindelo") and Radio
Morabeza in Mindelo.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

### Music[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cape_Verde&action=edit&section=29 "Edit
section: Music")]

Further information: [Music of Cape Verde](/wiki/Music_of_Cape_Verde "Music of
Cape Verde")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/23/Ces%C3%A1ria_%C3%89vora_%283%29.jpg/220px-
Ces%C3%A1ria_%C3%89vora_%283%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Ces%C3%A1ria_%C3%89vora_\(3\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Ces%C3%A1ria_%C3%89vora_\(3\).jpg "Enlarge")

[Cesária Évora](/wiki/Ces%C3%A1ria_%C3%89vora "Cesária Évora"), Cape Verdean
singer

The Cape Verdean people are known for their musicality, well expressed by
popular manifestations such as the Carnival of Mindelo, whose importance makes
the city known in the days of the momesque celebrations as "Brazilim" (or
"little Brazil"). Cape Verde music incorporates "African, Portuguese and
Brazilian influences."[64] Cape Verde's quintessential national music is the
_[morna](/wiki/Morna_\(music\) "Morna \(music\)")_ , a melancholy and lyrical
song form typically sung in [Cape Verdean Creole](/wiki/Cape_Verdean_Creole
"Cape Verdean Creole"). The most popular music genre after
_[morna](/wiki/Morna_\(music\) "Morna \(music\)")_ is the
_[coladeira](/wiki/Coladeira "Coladeira")_ , followed by
_[funaná](/wiki/Funan%C3%A1 "Funaná")_ and _[batuque](/wiki/Batuque_\(music\)
"Batuque \(music\)")_ music. [Cesária Évora](/wiki/Ces%C3%A1ria_%C3%89vora
"Cesária Évora") was the best-known Cape Verdean singer in the world, known as
the "barefoot diva", because she liked to perform barefooted on stage. The
international success of Cesária Évora has made other Cape Verdean artists, or
descendants of Cape Verdeans born in Portugal, gain more space in the music
market. Examples of this are singers Sara Tavares, Lura and [Mayra
Andrade](/wiki/Mayra_Andrade "Mayra Andrade").

Another great exponent of traditional music from Cape Verde was Antonio
Vicente Lopes, better known as Travadinha and [Ildo Lobo](/wiki/Ildo_Lobo
"Ildo Lobo"), who died in 2004. The House of Culture in the center of the city
of Praia is called Ildo Lobo House of Culture, in his honor.

There are also well known artists born to Cape Verdean parents who excelled
themselves in the international music scene. Amongst these artists are jazz
pianist [Horace Silver](/wiki/Horace_Silver "Horace Silver"), [Duke
Ellington](/wiki/Duke_Ellington "Duke Ellington")'s saxophonist [Paul
Gonsalves](/wiki/Paul_Gonsalves "Paul Gonsalves"), [Teófilo
Chantre](/wiki/Te%C3%B3filo_Chantre "Teófilo Chantre"), [Paul
Pena](/wiki/Paul_Pena "Paul Pena"), the [Tavares](/wiki/Tavares_\(group\)
"Tavares \(group\)") brothers and singer [Lura](/wiki/Lura_\(musician\) "Lura
\(musician\)").

### Dance[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cape_Verde&action=edit&section=30 "Edit
section: Dance")]

Dance forms include the soft dance _morna_ , the extreme sensuality of
_[coladeira](/wiki/Coladeira "Coladeira")_ , the Cape Verdean version of the
[zouk](/wiki/Zouk "Zouk") from [Guadeloupe](/wiki/Guadeloupe "Guadeloupe")
called _[Cabo love](/wiki/Cabo_love "Cabo love")_ , the
_[Funaná](/wiki/Funan%C3%A1 "Funaná")_ (a sensual mixed Portuguese and African
dance), and the _[Batuque](/wiki/Batuque_\(music\) "Batuque \(music\)")_
dance.

### Literature[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cape_Verde&action=edit&section=31
"Edit section: Literature")]

Cape Verdean literature is one of the richest of [Lusophone](/wiki/Lusophone
"Lusophone") Africa. Famous poets include Paulino Vieira, Manuel de Novas,
Sergio Frusoni, Eugénio Tavares, and B. Léza, and famous authors include
[Baltasar Lopes da Silva](/wiki/Baltasar_Lopes_da_Silva "Baltasar Lopes da
Silva"), António Aurélio Gonçalves, [Manuel Lopes](/wiki/Manuel_Lopes "Manuel
Lopes"), [Orlanda Amarílis](/wiki/Orlanda_Amar%C3%ADlis "Orlanda Amarílis"),
[Henrique Teixeira de Sousa](/wiki/Henrique_Teixeira_de_Sousa "Henrique
Teixeira de Sousa"), [Arménio Vieira](/wiki/Arm%C3%A9nio_Vieira "Arménio
Vieira"), Kaubverdianu Dambará, Dr. Azágua, and [Germano
Almeida](/wiki/Germano_Almeida "Germano Almeida").

### Cinema[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cape_Verde&action=edit&section=32 "Edit
section: Cinema")]

The Carnival and the island of [São
Vicente](/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Vicente,_Cape_Verde "São Vicente, Cape Verde") is
portrayed in the 2015 feature documentary _[Tchindas](/wiki/Tchindas
"Tchindas")_ , nominated at the [12th Africa Movie Academy
Awards](/wiki/12th_Africa_Movie_Academy_Awards "12th Africa Movie Academy
Awards").

### Cuisine[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cape_Verde&action=edit&section=33 "Edit
section: Cuisine")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/64/Cachupa_2.jpg/220px-
Cachupa_2.jpg)](/wiki/File:Cachupa_2.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Cachupa_2.jpg "Enlarge")

Cachupa

Main article: [Cape Verdean cuisine](/wiki/Cape_Verdean_cuisine "Cape Verdean
cuisine")

The Cape Verde diet is mostly based on fish and staple foods like corn and
rice. Vegetables available during most of the year are potatoes, onions,
tomatoes, [manioc](/wiki/Manioc "Manioc"), cabbage, kale, and dried beans.
Fruits such as bananas and [papayas](/wiki/Papaya "Papaya") are available
year-round, while others like [mangoes](/wiki/Mango "Mango") and
[avocados](/wiki/Avocado "Avocado") are seasonal.[27]

A popular dish served in Cape Verde is [Cachupa](/wiki/Cachupa "Cachupa"), a
slow cooked stew of corn (hominy), beans, and fish or meat. A common appetizer
is the [pastel](/wiki/Pastel_\(food\) "Pastel \(food\)") which is a pastry
shell filled with fish or meat that is then fried.[27]

### Sports[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cape_Verde&action=edit&section=34 "Edit
section: Sports")]

The country's most successful sports team is the [Cape Verde national
basketball team](/wiki/Cape_Verde_national_basketball_team "Cape Verde
national basketball team"), which won the bronze medal at the [FIBA Africa
Championship 2007](/wiki/FIBA_Africa_Championship_2007 "FIBA Africa
Championship 2007"), after beating
[Egypt](/wiki/Egypt_national_basketball_team "Egypt national basketball team")
in its last game. The country's most well-known player is [Walter
Tavares](/wiki/Walter_Tavares "Walter Tavares"), who plays for Real Madrid of
Spain.

Cape Verde is famous for wave sailing (a type of windsurfing) and
[kiteboarding](/wiki/Kitesurfing "Kitesurfing"). Josh Angulo, a Hawaiian and
2009 PWA Wave World Champion, has done much to promote the archipelago as a
[windsurfing](/wiki/Windsurfing "Windsurfing") destination. Cape Verde is now
his adopted country. Mitu Monteiro, a local kitesurfer, was the 2008 [Kite
Surfing World
Champion](/wiki/International_Kiteboarding_Association#Wave_Riding
"International Kiteboarding Association") in the wave discipline.

The [Cape Verde national football
team](/wiki/Cape_Verde_national_football_team "Cape Verde national football
team"), nicknamed either the _Tubarões Azuis_ (Blue Sharks) or _Crioulos_
(Creoles), is the national team of Cape Verde and is controlled by the
[Federação Caboverdiana de
Futebol](/wiki/Federa%C3%A7%C3%A3o_Caboverdiana_de_Futebol "Federação
Caboverdiana de Futebol"). The team has played at two [Africa Cup of
Nations](/wiki/Africa_Cup_of_Nations "Africa Cup of Nations"), in
[2013](/wiki/2013_Africa_Cup_of_Nations "2013 Africa Cup of Nations") and
[2015](/wiki/2015_Africa_Cup_of_Nations "2015 Africa Cup of Nations").[65]

The country has competed at every [Summer Olympics](/wiki/Summer_Olympics
"Summer Olympics") since 1996.

## Transport[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cape_Verde&action=edit&section=35 "Edit
section: Transport")]

Main article: [Transport in Cape Verde](/wiki/Transport_in_Cape_Verde
"Transport in Cape Verde")

### Ports[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cape_Verde&action=edit&section=36 "Edit
section: Ports")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/CaisPortoNovo.JPG/220px-
CaisPortoNovo.JPG)](/wiki/File:CaisPortoNovo.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:CaisPortoNovo.JPG "Enlarge")

New port in Santo Antão

There are four international ports: Mindelo, São Vicente; Praia, Santiago;
Palmeira, Sal; and Sal Rei, Boa Vista. Mindelo on São Vicente is the main port
for cruise liners and the terminus for the ferry service to Santo Antão. Praia
on Santiago is a main hub for local ferry services to other islands. Palmeira
on Sal supplies fuel for the main airport on the island, Amílcar Cabral
International Airport, and is important for the hotel construction taking
place on the island. Porto Novo on Santo Antão is the only source for imports
and exports of produce from the island as well as passenger traffic since the
closure of the airstrip at Ponta do Sol. There are smaller harbors,
essentially single jetties at Tarrafal on São Nicolau, Sal Rei on Boa Vista,
Vila do Maio (Porto Inglês) on Maio, São Filipe on Fogo and Furna on Brava.
These act as terminals for the inter-island ferry services, which carry both
freight and passengers. The pier at Santa Maria on Sal used by both fishing
and dive boats has been rehabilitated.
